title: 104_hr125
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress emphasizes the duty of government to protect citizens from armed criminals to maintain public safety. Banning specific firearms does not deter criminals from acquiring weapons to harm innocent people. The most effective way to protect the public from gun violence is not by restricting certain types of firearms. Banning specific types of firearms does not deter criminals from acquiring weapons to harm innocent people. The most effective way to protect the public from gun-wielding violent criminals is to arrest, convict, and incarcerate such predators with sufficient sentences to prevent quick return to the streets. The Armed Violent Criminal Apprehension Directive aims to arrest, convict, and incarcerate gun-wielding violent criminals with sufficient sentences to prevent quick return to the streets. The Attorney General of the United States will establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. Each US attorney must designate a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets. The violent criminal apprehension task force will develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets, considering the importance of severe punishment, effectiveness of laws, resources available to law enforcement agencies, and the nature of violent crime. The violent criminal apprehension task force will consider the resources available to law enforcement agencies, the nature of violent crime in the district, and the principle of limited Federal involvement in prosecuting crimes traditionally handled by State and local jurisdictions. The Attorney General will require monthly reports from United States attorneys on the number of defendants charged with violent crimes. The Attorney General mandates monthly reports from United States attorneys on defendants charged with violating specific sections of the United States Code. Additionally, biannual reports to Congress include information on waivers granted under subsection (b). The Attorney General submits biannual reports to Congress containing information on waivers granted under subsection (b) and data received from United States attorneys on defendants charged with violating specific sections of the United States Code. The Attorney General may waive the requirements of subsection (a) for United States attorneys based on guidelines considering the number of assistant United States attorneys and the level of violent crime in the district. The Attorney General may waive the requirements for United States attorneys based on guidelines considering the level of violent crime in the district. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as a person accused of violating certain sections of the United States Code. This section will expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Repeal of prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by removing subsections (v) and (w) and the appendix. Section 921(a) is amended by striking paragraph (30). Section 921(a)(31)(A) is amended by removing certain phrases. Section 923(i) is amended by removing the last 2 sentences. Section 924(a)(1)(B) is amended by changing the specified sections to just "(r)". Section 923(i) of title 18, United States Code is amended by removing the last 2 sentences. Section 924(a)(1)(B) is amended by changing the specified sections to just "(r)". Section 110104 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is repealed. SEC. 5 mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include harsher penalties for individuals who possess a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Individuals who possess a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking face harsh penalties, including 5 years imprisonment for possession, 10 years for brandishing, and additional sentencing for discharging with intent to injure. Individuals who discharge a firearm with the intent to injure another person during a crime of violence or drug trafficking face harsh penalties, including an additional 20 years of imprisonment. If the firearm is a short-barreled rifle, short-barreled shotgun, or equipped with certain features, the additional sentence is 10 years more than the standard penalty. The additional sentence for possessing a firearm during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking is 30 years if the firearm is a machinegun or destructive device, and 10 years for other firearms. If a person possessed, brandished, or discharged a firearm during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they will face additional imprisonment of 20 years, 25 years, or more, respectively. If a person discharged a firearm with the intent to injure another person during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they will face additional imprisonment of not less than 30 years, especially if the firearm is a machinegun or destructive device. If a person is convicted of a second or subsequent offense involving a firearm, they face imprisonment for not less than 30 years. However, if the firearm is a machinegun or destructive device, they will be sentenced to life imprisonment. The court cannot impose probation or concurrent sentences for violations of this subsection. A person convicted of a firearm offense will not receive probation and their imprisonment term will not run concurrently with other offenses. They will not be released for any reason during their imprisonment term. The House of Representatives passed the document on March 22, 1996, as attested by Robin H. Carle, Clerk.
